title: Now that Trump is for masks, how will his supporters respond? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Is he, though? As with almost every issue, he’s on every side of the issue. He says what seems easiest for him in any given moment, but feels no obligation to stick with any particular position or act consistently with his latest position. It’s typically very obvious what his real position is though because he might make 300 statements on an issue and only 5 or 10 of them go one way, and all the others go the other way. This gives him and his supporters the ability to point to those other statements when convenient, as a defense, but it’s rarely difficult for his followers to discern what he really wants when the vast majority of his statements go the other way. Not only do they go the other way, they’re typically far more loud and intense, as well as spontaneous. Conversely, the ones he doesn’t really mean but just says to give a fig leaf of deniability or to squirm out of a tough question, are usually more soft spoken and half-hearted, more equivocal with slippery qualifiers, and not repeated much. Add to that the fact that he avoids ever being seen wearing a mask, and has mocked those who do, and it’s really not difficult to see where he stands on that particular issue. If he were to truly reverse himself on masks and mean it, there’d be no doubt. He’d say it loud, proud, and often, across every medium, with the vitriolic fury he’s notorious for. Therefore, to answer the question, his supporters won’t respond until he means it, and he clearly doesn’t mean it. He doesn’t want to see people wearing masks because it’s the clearest possible sign that the pandemic is real, not a hoax, and not at all under control. He cares much less about whether it is under control than whether it looks like it’s under control. He cares about “the numbers” but not the people. It’s why he wants testing reduced and why he wanted to strand Americans on cruise ships. He told us himself, he liked where the numbers were and didn’t want them to go up. He cares about the economy, but not the people who run it. That’s why he rushed to get everyone back out, before the problem was addressed and before any of them met his own government’s guidance for when that would be safe. That’s why he’s now running around threatening states and schools with funding cuts if they don’t fully open, even when they can’t meet his own government’s guidance for safe reopening. Is he trying to help solve their challenges? Get them more resources? No, he’s trying to get the standards dropped and threatening anyone who stands in his way. Why? Because he cares about education? Because he cares about public safety? No to both. It’s because he knows people can’t get back to work without child care. It’s all about the economy, which is all about his reelection. He cares about his reelection, but not the people he’s supposed to serve. And he maintains the ridiculous belief that ignoring the dangers and pretending they’re not there is better than addressing them. He wants the grandeur of accomplishment without doing the work to earn and deserve it. He wants to skip the hard work of solving the problem and go right to the celebration and benefits of having solved it. His every action bears this out.
